sen.j: 基礎情報 天皇
sen.e: Personal information of Emperor SHIRAKAWA
Personal information of Emperor SHIRAKAWA
Personal information of Emperor SHIRAKAWA

sen.j: 白河天皇（しらかわ てんのう、天喜元年6月19日 (旧暦)（1053年7月7日） - 大治4年7月7日 (旧暦)（1129年7月24日））は、第72代の天皇。
sen.e: Emperor SHIRAKAWA (7th July 1053 - 24th July 1129) was the 72nd Emperor. According to the old Japanese calendar he lived from 19th June Tengi 1 to 7th July Daiji 4.
Emperor SHIRAKAWA (7th July 1053 - 24th July 1129) was the 72nd Emperor.
sen.cmt: 長いし、2つ並べて書くとかえって混乱。
sen.e: Emperor SHIRAKAWA (7th July 1053 - 24th July 1129) was the 72nd Emperor.

sen.j: 在位は延久4年12月8日 (旧暦)（1073年1月18日） - 応徳3年11月26日 (旧暦)（1087年1月5日）。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA came to power on the 18th January 1073 and reigned until 5th January 1087 or in the old Japanese calendar 8th December Enkyu 4 to 26th November Otoku 3)
SHIRAKAWA came to power on the 18th January 1073 and reigned until 5th January 1087.
SHIRAKAWA came to power on the 18th January 1073 and reigned until 5th anuary 1087.

sen.j: 諱を貞仁（さだひと）という。
sen.e: His first name was Sadahito.
Is posthumously known as Sadahito.
His posthumous name was Sadahito.

sen.j: 藤原氏摂家と外戚関係の薄い後三条天皇の第一皇子として生まれ、母は藤原氏閑院流出身で中納言藤原公成の娘、春宮大夫藤原能信の養女である女御藤原茂子（?-1062）。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA was the first son of Emperor Go-Sanjo who had no maternal relationship to the Fujiwara Five Regent Houses however his mother, Nyogo, FUJIWARA no Moshi/Shigeko from Fujiwara Kaninryu, the daughter of Chunagon FUJIWARA no Kinnari, was the adopted daughter of Togu Daibu FUJIWARA no Yoshinobu.

SHIRAKAWA was the first son of Emperor Go-Sanjo who had little maternal relationship with the Fujiwara Five Regent Houses, and his mother, Nyogo, FUJIWARA no Moshi/Shigeko was from Fujiwara Kaninryu, the daughter of Chunagon FUJIWARA no Kinnari, and the adopted daughter of Togu Daibu FUJIWARA no Yoshinobu.
sen.cmt: 関係が「薄い」ので no ではなく、little を使った。 前否定の意味はないので、however ではなく、 and を使った。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA was the first son of Emperor Go-Sanjo who had little maternal relationship with the Fujiwara Five Regent Houses, and his mother, Nyogo, FUJIWARA no Moshi/Shigeko was from Fujiwara Kaninryu, the daughter of Chunagon FUJIWARA no Kinnari, and the adopted daughter of Togu Daibu FUJIWARA no Yoshinobu.

sen.j: 同母妹に篤子内親王（堀河天皇中宮）。
sen.e: His half sister was Princess Tokushi/Atsuko (Empress of Horikawa)
His half sister was Princess Tokushi/Atsuko (Empress of Horikawa)
His half sister was Princess Tokushi/Atsuko (Empress of Horikawa)

sen.j: 系図
sen.e: Genealogy
Genealogy
Genealogy

sen.j: 幼い時は父子ともに冷遇されたが、治暦4年（1068年）、父帝即位とともに親王宣下を受け貞仁親王となる。
sen.e: Although he and his father were snubbed due to their background, after his father was enthroned in 1068 (Jiryaku 4), he was proclaimed a Shinno (Imperial prince) and became Imperial Prince Sadahito.

When he was young, he and his father were snubbed due to their background, but after his father was enthroned in 1068 (Jiryaku 4), he was proclaimed a Shinno (Imperial prince) and became Imperial Prince Sadahito.

When he was young, he and his father were snubbed due to their background, but after his father was enthroned in 1068 (Jiryaku 4), he was proclaimed a Shinno (Imperial prince) and became Imperial Prince Sadahito.

sen.j: 翌延久元年（1069年）立太子、同4年、20歳で即位。
sen.e: In 1069 (Enkyu 1, equivalent to Jiryaku 4) he became Crown Prince when he was twenty years old.
In 1069 he became Crown Prince, and became an Emperor three years later, when he was twenty years old.
sen.cmt: カッコ内の年号の説明は不要なので省略。即位した（天皇になった）部分が抜けていたので加えた。
sen.e: In 1069 he became Crown Prince, and became an Emperor three years later, when he was twenty years old.

sen.j: 関白を置いたが、翌5年、上皇の病没後も、父同様に親政を目指し、荘園整理などに力を入れ摂関家の権勢を弱めることに努める。
sen.e: A Kanpaku was put in place, but Shirakawa attempted to rule directly like his father had done, after his father died of illness in 1070 (Jiryaku 5), and also attempted to regulate the Shoen(manor) system working to weaken the influence of the Sekkan lines.

A Kanpaku was assigned, but SHIRAKAWA attempted to rule directly like his father had done, after his father, the retired Emperor, died of illness in 1070 (Jiryaku 5), and also attempted to regulate the Shoen(manor) system thereby trying to weaken the influence of the Regent/Kanpaku Houses.
sen.cmt: 父のところに、「上皇」を加えた。”Ｓｅｋｋａｎ ｌｉｎｅ”だと意味がよくわからないので、変えた。
sen.e: A Kanpaku was assigned, but SHIRAKAWA attempted to rule directly like his father had done, after his father, the retired Emperor, died of illness in 1070 (Jiryaku 5), and also attempted to regulate the Shoen(manor) system thereby trying to weaken the influence of the Regent/Kanpaku Houses.

sen.j: 後三条院とその生母である陽明門院は白河天皇の異母弟実仁親王 (平安時代)更にその弟の輔仁親王に皇位を継がせる意志を持ち、譲位時に実仁親王を皇太弟と定めた。
sen.e: Go-Sanjo-in and his mother Yomeimon-in, wished for either SHIRAKAWA's younger half brother, Prince Sanehito (Heian period) or his younger brother Prince Sukehito to succeed to the throne and later on it was decided Prince Sanehito would be Prince.

Go-Sanjo-in and Go-Sanjo-in`s mother, Yomeimon-in, wished for SHIRAKAWA's younger half brother, Prince Sanehito (Heian period) and then Sanehito`s younger brother Prince Sukehito to succeed to the throne, and upon abdication to SHIRAKAWA, Prince Sanehito was decided to become Crown Prince.
sen.cmt: "His" だと、誰のことだかあいまいなので、名前を入れてはっきりさせた。「更に」は、 "or"ではないので、直した。
sen.e: Go-Sanjo-in and Go-Sanjo-in's mother, Yomeimon-in, wished for SHIRAKAWA's younger half brother, Prince Sanehito (Heian period) and then Sanehito`s younger brother Prince Sukehito to succeed to the throne, and upon abdication to SHIRAKAWA, Prince Sanehito was decided to become Crown Prince.

sen.j: 白河天皇はこれに反発したが応徳2年（1085年）実仁親王は病没した。
sen.e: SHIRAKARA did not accept this and later Prince Sanehiro died from illness in 1085 (Otoku 2).
SHIRAKARA repelled against this and later Prince Sanehiro died from illness in 1085 (Otoku 2).
sen.cmt: 受け入れなかったのではなく、反発した。
sen.e: SHIRAKARA repelled against this and later Prince Sanehiro died from illness in 1085 (Otoku 2).

sen.j: これにより、応徳3年11月（1086年）、白河天皇は輔仁親王ではなく、8歳のわが子の善仁親王（第73代堀河天皇）を皇太子に立て、即日譲位した。
sen.e: As a result, in 1086 (November, Otoku 3), Shirakawa proclaimed his own eight year old son, Prince Taruhito (73rd Emperor Horikawa) to be the next prince instead of Prince Sukehito and he immediately became Crown Prince.

As a result, in November, 1086 (Otoku 3), SHIRAKAWA proclaimed his own eight year old son, Prince Taruhito (73rd Emperor Horikawa) to be the Crown Prince instead of Prince Sukehito and SHIRAKAWA abdicated immediately.
sen.cmt: 白河が堀河に譲位した。
sen.e: As a result, in November, 1086 (Otoku 3), SHIRAKAWA proclaimed his own eight year old son, Prince Taruhito (73rd Emperor Horikawa) to be the Crown Prince instead of Prince Sukehito and SHIRAKAWA abdicated immediately.

sen.j: 太上天皇となった白河上皇は、幼帝を後見するために白河院として自ら政務を執り、いわゆる院政が出現した。
sen.e: Even though SHIRAKAWA's son was prince he was too young to rule and although SHIRAKAWA was retired he still retained power and ruled indirectly from a place called Shirakawa-in and this style of government was to become known as insei (cloistered style).

Retired Emperor SHIRAKAWA, who became Daijo Tenno, acted as the guardian of the young Emperor, and ruled personally as Shirakawa-in, and this style of government became known as Insei system (cloistered style).
sen.cmt: 最初の部分は、日本語どおりに。
sen.e: Retired Emperor SHIRAKAWA, who became Daijo Tenno, acted as the guardian of the young Emperor, and ruled personally as Shirakawa-in, and this style of government became known as Insei system (cloistered style).

sen.j: 引き続き摂政関白は置かれたものの、これにより名目上の存在に近いものとなる。
sen.e: Although the Sessho and Kampaku offices continued, they did not have actual power to rule the government.
Through such system, although the Sessho and Kampaku offices continued, they did not have actual power to rule the government.
sen.cmt: 「これにより」を最初に加えた。
sen.e: Through such system, although the Sessho and Kampaku offices continued, they did not have actual power to rule the government.

sen.j: 白河上皇は堀河天皇の成人後も政権を返すことなく、受領階級や武家出身の近臣を用いて専制的な政治を行った。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA continued to have exert power even after Emperor Horikawa turned twenty years old and he strengthened his position by appointing aids from the Juryro and Samurai class.
SHIRAKAWA continued to have exert power even after Emperor Horikawa turned twenty years old and he strengthened his despotic position by appointing aids from the Juryro and Samurai class.
SHIRAKAWA continued to have exert power even after Emperor Horikawa turned twenty years old and he strengthened his despotic position by appointing aids from the Juryro and Samurai class.

sen.j: 武士は、院の警護役として創設した北面の武士になどにあてた。
sen.e: The group of Samurai soldiers organized were called the "Hokumen no bushi" and were ordered to protect the Shirakawa-in.
sen.cmt: 北面の武士→Hokumen no Bushiを追加しました。
sen.e: The Samurai soldiers were assigned to such posts as the "Hokumen no bushi" which was newly established to protect the retired Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「創設した」 「など」の意味を加えた。
sen.e: The Samurai soldiers were assigned to such posts as the "Hokumen no bushi" which was newly established to protect the retired Emperor.

sen.j: 熱心に仏教を信じ、嘉保3年（1096年）には皇女の病没を機に出家し法名を融観とし、法皇となった。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA was a strict Buddhist and he became a high ranking monk called Yukan after the death of his daughter in 1096 (Kaho 3).
sen.cmt: 法皇→Cloistered Emperor を、a high ranking monkとしました。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA was a strict Buddhist and he became a Cloistered Emperor with Buddhist name of Yukan after the death of his daughter in 1096 (Kaho 3).
sen.cmt: "high ranking monk"だと、「高位の僧」なので変。「法名」を加えた。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA was a strict Buddhist and he became a Cloistered Emperor with posthumous Buddhist name of Yukan after the death of his daughter in 1096 (Kaho 3).

sen.j: また法勝寺等の多くの寺院や仏像をつくらせたが、その経済力は受領の経済力を活用した。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA ordered the building of many temples and Buddhist statues including the Hossho-ji Temple, he took advantage of getting finance from Juryo.
SHIRAKAWA ordered the building of many temples and Buddhist statues including the Hossho-ji Temple, and he took advantage of getting finance from Juryo.
SHIRAKAWA ordered the building of many temples and Buddhist statues including the Hossho-ji Temple, and he took advantage of getting finance from Juryo.

sen.j: 堀河天皇崩御後は、その皇子で自らの孫である第74代鳥羽天皇、更にその子の第75代崇徳天皇と3代にわたって幼主を擁し、大治4年7月7日（1129年7月24日）、77歳で崩御するまで実に3代43年間院政を敷いた。
sen.e: After Emperor Horikawa died, SHIRAKAWA ruled using a cloistered government for forty three years until he died on 24th July 1129 (7th July Taiji 4), supporting both his grandson 74th Emperor Toba and his great grandson 75th Emperor Sutoku through three generations.

After Emperor Horikawa died, SHIRAKAWA ruled using a cloistered government for forty three years through three generations of young Emperors, until he died on 24th July 1129 (7th July Taiji 4), and he supported both his grandson 74th Emperor Toba and his great grandson 75th Emperor Sutoku.

After Emperor Horikawa died, SHIRAKAWA ruled using a cloistered government for forty three years through three generations of young Emperors, until he died on 24th July 1129 (7th July Taiji 4), and he supported both his grandson 74th Emperor Toba and his great grandson 75th Emperor Sutoku.

sen.j: これを「治天の君」という。
sen.e: This is called "Chiten no kimi".
sen.cmt: 治天の君→Tenchi no kimiを、 Chiten no kimiに訂正しました。
sen.e: This is called "Chiten no kimi".
This is called "Chiten no kimi".

sen.j: 白河法皇が「天下の三不如意―鴨川 (淀川水系)（鴨川）の水（鴨川の流れとそれによる水害）・双六の賽（サイコロ、当時の双六（ただし、現在のものと違い西洋のバックギャモンに近い）は賭博の手段として盛んに用いられて、さいころの目の動きが勝敗を分けた）・山法師（比叡山延暦寺の僧衆〔僧兵〕）」だけはどうしようもないと嘆いたという故事は、裏を返せば彼がそれ以外のものであれば思い通りにならない事はないという絶大な権力を誇っていたことを示している。
sen.e: The Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa had supreme power however it was said he mentioned there are three things which he does not have control over 1. the Kamo River (that become the Yodo River), due to frequent flooding) 2. The popularity of gambling using dice game like backgammon 3. The Yamaboshi (monk fighters from Mt. Hie Enryaku-ji Temple.) This proves SHIRAKAWA had absolute control apart from these three things.

The Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa had supreme power, but it was said he lamented that, he has no control over the following three things: 1. Waters of the Kamo River (tributary of the Yodo River)(due to its flow and frequent flooding); 2. Dice used in sugoroku (different from current sugoroku, close to western backgammon), which was popular way of gambling at that time, with spots on the dice selecting winners/losers; and 3. Yamaboshi (monk soldiers from Mt. Hie Enryaku-ji Temple), which show that SHIRAKAWA had absolute control apart from these three things.
sen.cmt: 淀川の支流、と解釈。「流れ」を加えた.すごろくの文は、後半が抜けていた。 その他、元の文に忠実にわかりやすく。
sen.e: The Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa had supreme power, but it was said he mented that, he has no control over the following three things: 1. Waters of the Kamo River (tributary of the Yodo River)(due to its flow and frequent flooding); 2. Dice used in sugoroku (different from current sugoroku, close to western backgammon), which was popular way of gambling at that time, with spots on the dice selecting winners/losers; and 3. Yamaboshi (monk soldiers from Mt. Hie Enryaku-ji Temple), which show that SHIRAKAWA had absolute control apart from these three things.

sen.j: また、女性関係の派手さでも知られており、崇徳天皇や平清盛が「白河法皇の御落胤」であるという噂が当時広く流布され信じられる原因ともなっている。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA had many relationships with women and there were rumors that Emperor Sutoku and TAIRA no Kiyomori could have been SHIRAKAWA'S illegitimate sons.
SHIRAKAWA is also known for many relationships with women and the rumor that Emperor Sutoku and TAIRA no Kiyomori may be SHIRAKAWA's illegitimate sons, was widely spread and believed at the time.
sen.cmt: 「知られており」「当時広く流布、信じられた」を加えた。
sen.e: SHIRAKAWA is also known for many relationships with women and the rumor that Emperor Sutoku and TAIRA no Kiyomori may be SHIRAKAWA's illegitimate sons, was widely spread and believed at the time.

tit.cmt: 后妃→Empress、皇子女→Princessを追加しました。

Empress, FUJIWARA no Kenshi/Kataiko (1057-1084) - the daughter of MINAMOTO no Akifusa and adopted daughter of FUJIWARA no Morozane
Empress, FUJIWARA no Kenshi/Kataiko (1057-1084) - the daughter of MINAMOTO no Akifusa and adopted daughter of FUJIWARA no Morozane

sen.e: Nyogo:FUJIWARA no Doshi/Michiko (1042-1132) was the daughter of FUJIWARA no Yoshinaga
Nyogo:FUJIWARA no Doshi/Michiko (1042-1132) was the daughter of FUJIWARA no Yoshinaga

sen.j: 典侍：藤原経子 - 藤原経平四女、後に藤原公定室
sen.e: Naishinosuke: FUJIWARA no Keishi/Tsuneko, was the forth daughter of FUJIWARA no Tsunehira, later became wife of FUJIWARA no Kinsada
Naishinosuke: FUJIWARA no Keishi/Tsuneko, was the fourth daughter of FUJIWARA no Tsunehira, and later became wife of FUJIWARA no Kinsada
Naishinosuke: FUJIWARA no Keishi/Tsuneko, was the fourth daughter of FUJIWARA no Tsunehira, and later became wife of FUJIWARA no Kinsada

sen.e: MINAMOTO no Moroko (1070-1148) was the daughter of MINAMOTO no Akifusa and later became wife of FUJIWARA no Tadazane.
MINAMOTO no Moroko (1070-1148) was the daughter of MINAMOTO no Akifusa and later became wife of FUJIWARA no Tadazane.

Iwaiwo (Kamonyogo) - daughter of Sigesuke KAMOAGATANUSHI
Iwaiwo (Kamonyogo) - daughter of igesuke KAMOAGATANUSHI

sen.j: 譲位後の院政時の住居の名称により、白河院と追号された（追号も諡号の一種とする場合もあるが、厳密には諡号とは異なる）。
sen.e: The name SHIRAKAWA comes from Shirakawa-in, the name of the residence from which he conducted his cloistered rule after abdicating the throne. (Sometimes Tsuigo is considered his pothumous name however strictly speaking these are two different names.)

The Tsuigo of Shirakawa-in comes from the name of the residence from which he conducted his cloistered rule after abdicating the throne (sometimes Tsuigo is considered to be a type of pothumous name, however strictly speaking these are two different names).
sen.cmt: 名前でなく、「白河院」という追号。
sen.e: The Tsuigo of Shirakawa-in comes from the name of the residence from which he conducted his cloistered rule after abdicating the throne (sometimes Tsuigo is considered to be a type of pothumous name, however strictly speaking these are two different names).

sen.j: また六条帝の異名もある。
sen.e: Shirakawa Emperor was also named Rokujotei.
SHIRAKAWA was also named Rokujotei.
SHIRAKAWA was also named Rokujotei.

sen.j: 大正以後は白河天皇とする。
sen.e: He named himself Emperor Shirakawa after Taisho period.
He was named Emperor SHIRAKAWA in and after Taisho period.
sen.cmt: 自分で名乗ったわけではない。 「以後」
sen.e: He was named Emperor SHIRAKAWA in and after Taisho period.

tit.e: During the region of the Year

sen.j: 延久
sen.e: Enkyu
Enkyu
Enkyu

sen.j: 永保
sen.e: Eiho
Eiho
Eiho

sen.j: 応徳
sen.e: Otoku
Otoku
Otoku

sen.j: 京都市伏見区竹田浄菩提院町の成菩提院陵（じょうぼだいいんのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Jobodaijin no misasagi located in Takedajobodaiincho, Fushimi district, Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Jobodaijin no misasagi located in Takedajobodaiincho, Fushimi district, Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Jobodaijin no misasagi located in Takedajobodaiincho, Fushimi district, Kyoto City.

sen.j: なお、この陵墓の近所には、別に同陵の有力な比定候補地が存在し、ここは陵墓参考地として、宮内庁の管轄地となっている。
sen.e: Tthere is another poosibility that Shirakaswa was entombed in Ryobo Sankouchi, an area regulated by the Imperial Houshold Agency and also close to Jobodaiin.
sen.cmt: 陵墓参考地→Ryobo sankouchiを追加しました。
sen.e: Near this Jobodaiin, there is another poosible place that SHIRAKAWA was entombed in, which is regulated by the Imperial Houshold Agency as Ryobo sankouchi.
Near this Jobodaiin, there is another poossible place that SHIRAKAWA was entombed in, which is regulated by the Imperial Household Agency as Ryobo sankouchi.

sen.j: また、全ての天皇は皇居の宮中三殿の一つの皇霊殿に祀られている。
sen.e: There are three palace sanctuaries, one called Koreiden where the souls of past emperors are supposed to dwell.
All the past Emperors are enshrined in Koreiden, one of the Three Palace Sanctuaries.
All the past Emperors are enshrined in Koreiden, one of the Three Palace Sanctuaries.

sen.j: また、白河法皇は当初、自身の死後は土葬されることを望み、たびたび周囲の者にその意向を伝えていたが、同様に土葬された藤原師通が、生前に彼と対立していた興福寺の僧兵が報復としてその墓を暴き、遺体を辱めんと計画していたことを知り、自身も後世に同様な仕打ちを受けるのを嫌い、急遽火葬にするように命じたという。
sen.e: Emperor Shirakawa's will was to be cremated after his death, often mentioned this to his people, later on he changed his will to be buried after knowing FUJIWARA no Moromichi who was cremated, his body was about to be attacked by a monk fighter of Kofuku-ji Temple, who was known as Fujiwara no Moromichi's opposition while he was alive.

Emperor Shirakawa initially wished to be buried after his death, and often mentioned this to his people, but he suddenly ordered to be cremated, when he learnt that the body of FUJIWARA no Moromichi, who was buried, was in the danger of being humiliated by monk soldiers of Kofuku-ji Temple, who were known to be opposed to Moromichi when Moromichi was alive, and planned to attack and open Moromichi's grave.
sen.cmt: 土葬と火葬が逆。あとは、原文どおり少し言葉を変え、入れ替えた。
sen.e: Emperor Shirakawa initially wished to be buried after his death, and often mentioned this to his people, but he suddenly ordered to be cremated, when he learnt that the body of FUJIWARA no Moromichi, who was buried, was in the danger of being humiliated by monk soldiers of Kofuku-ji Temple, who were known to be opposed to Moromichi when Moromichi was alive, and planned to attack and open Moromichi's grave.

sen.j: 法皇の遺体を荼毘に付したとされる火葬塚は京都市北区 (京都市)の金閣小学校の近くに現存する。
sen.e: It is said the Emperor's body was cremated in the Kita district, Kyoto City at a crematorium that still exist near the Kinkaku Elementary School.
It is said the Emperor's body was cremated in the Kita district, Kyoto City at a crematorium, monument of which still exists near the Kinkaku Elementary School.
sen.cmt: 火葬塚は火葬場そのものではなく、遺跡のようなもの。
sen.e: It is said the Emperor's body was cremated in the Kita district, Kyoto City at a crematorium, monument of which still exists near the Kinkaku Elementary School.

sen.j: 美川 圭『白河法皇 中世をひらいた帝王』（日本放送出版協会、2003年） ISBN 4140019735
sen.e: Kei MIKAWA "Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa – The Emperor who started Cloistered Rule" published by Japan Broadcast Publishing Association in 2003. ISBN 4140019735
sen.cmt: Japan Broadcast Publishing の後に、Associationを付け加えました。
sen.e: Kei MIKAWA "Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa – The Emperor who started Cloistered Rule" published by Japan Broadcast Publishing Association in 2003. ISBN 4140019735

sen.e: "The New Tale of the Heike" 1955 (movie directed by Kenji MIZOGUCHI, SHIRAKAWA played by Eijiro YANAGI)
